sn54.10:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kimbilā in the Freshwater Mangrove Wood.
sn54.10:1.3: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Kimbila,
sn54.10:1.4: “Kimbila, how is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
sn54.10:2.1: When he said this, Kimbila kept silent.
sn54.10:2.3: And for a third time, the Buddha said to him,
sn54.10:2.4: “How is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
sn54.10:2.5: And a second time and a third time Kimbila kept silent.
sn54.10:3.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
sn54.10:3.2: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
sn54.10:3.3: Let the Buddha speak on immersion due to mindfulness of breathing. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
sn54.10:4.1: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn54.10:4.4: “Ānanda, how is immersion due to mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so that it is very fruitful and beneficial?
sn54.10:4.5: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, sits down cross-legged, with their body straight, and establishes mindfulness right there.
sn54.10:4.6: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out. …
sn54.10:4.7: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
sn54.10:4.8: That’s how immersion due to mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.
sn54.10:5.1: When a mendicant is breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ When breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
sn54.10:5.2: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ When breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
sn54.10:5.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
sn54.10:5.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
sn54.10:5.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:5.7: Because the breath is a certain aspect of the body, I say.
sn54.10:5.8: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:6.1: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’
sn54.10:6.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing bliss.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing bliss.’
sn54.10:6.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mental processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mental processes.’
sn54.10:6.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental processes.’
sn54.10:6.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:6.7: Because close focus on the breath is a certain aspect of feelings, I say.
sn54.10:6.8: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:7.1: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’
sn54.10:7.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out gladdening the mind.’
sn54.10:7.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in immersing the mind in samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out immersing the mind in samādhi.’
sn54.10:7.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’
sn54.10:7.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:7.7: Because there is no development of immersion due to mindfulness of breathing for someone who is unmindful and lacks awareness, I say.
sn54.10:7.8: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:8.1: There’s a time when a mendicant practices like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’
sn54.10:8.2: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing fading away.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing fading away.’
sn54.10:8.3: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing cessation.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing cessation.’
sn54.10:8.4: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
sn54.10:8.5: At such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:8.6: Having seen with wisdom the giving up of desire and aversion, they watch closely over with equanimity.
sn54.10:8.7: Therefore, at such a time a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
sn54.10:9.1: Suppose there was a large heap of sand at the crossroads.
sn54.10:9.2: And a cart or chariot were to come by from the east,
sn54.10:9.5: or south and destroy that heap of sand.
sn54.10:9.6: In the same way, when a mendicant is meditating by observing an aspect of the body,
sn54.10:9.9: or principles, they destroy bad, unskillful qualities.”
